title: Ticket #1571: AnalyzePolicy() returns the wrong value for an invalid TimerRemove
description:
UserPolicy::AnalyzePolicy() doesn't return UNDEFINED_EVAL when used with a ClassAd that has an unidentified value for the ATTR_TIMER_REMOVE_CHECK attribute.

The unit test output: 

TEST:  Test that AnalyzePolicy() returns UNDEFINED_EVAL when used with a ClassAd that has TimerRemove evaluate to undefined.
INPUT:
    ClassAd:  [ PeriodicRemove = true; PeriodicHold = true; JobStatus = 2; PeriodicRelease = true; TimerRemove = DoesNotExist; OnExitRemove = true; OnExitHold = true; CurrentTime = time() ]
    Mode:  PERIODIC_ONLY
EXPECTED OUTPUT:
    RETURN:  3
ACTUAL OUTPUT:
    RETURN:  2
RESULT:  FAILURE, test failed at line 531 (0 seconds)
remarks:
2010-Aug-12 10:33:06 by slauson:
Here's a fix for #1571, #1572, #1573, #1574, #1575. 
--- a/src/condor_c++_util/user_job_policy.cpp
+++ b/src/condor_c++_util/user_job_policy.cpp
@@ -446,10 +446,18 @@ UserPolicy::AnalyzePolicy( int mode )
    /* Should I perform a remove based on the epoch time? */
    m_fire_expr = ATTR_TIMER_REMOVE_CHECK;
    if(!m_ad->LookupInteger(ATTR_TIMER_REMOVE_CHECK, timer_remove)) {
+       //check if attribute exists, but is undefined
+       if(m_ad->Lookup(ATTR_TIMER_REMOVE_CHECK) != NULL)
+       {
+           m_fire_expr_val = -1;
+           m_fire_source = FS_JobAttribute;
+           return UNDEFINED_EVAL;
+       }
        timer_remove = -1;
    }
    if( timer_remove >= 0 && timer_remove < time(NULL) ) {
        m_fire_expr_val = 1;
+       m_fire_source = FS_JobAttribute;
        return REMOVE_FROM_QUEUE;
    }

2010-Aug-12 11:23:53 by jfrey:
I've reviewed the patch and it looks good.
check_ins: 2010-Aug-12 11:27   Check-in [18783]: Updated UserPolicy::AnalyzePolicy() so that an undefined TimerRemove attribute is handled like other undefined UserPolicy attributes. (#1571, #1572, #1573, #1574) (By Josh Slauson )
